narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: We learned about various trade models and econometric techniques like fixed effects estimations. Emphasis was placed on General Equilibrium trade models, including the Armington C.E.S. Model, Ricardian framework, and more recent seminal papers like Eaton's & Kortum's probabilistic production. The course concluded with a framework for understanding intermediate goods trade through input-output linkages and a discussion about how the COVID-19 pandemic affect international trade in the past year.
learned how to read and understand overviews of a lot of economic trade papers.
This course taught us how to evaluate contemporary papers and learn the tools, equations, and theories that model international trade.
understanding the intuitions behind seminal models in trade research, interpreting research outcomes beyond reciting numbers

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The lectures were specifically made for the course and were very understandable and informative everyday. The exams were fair, and there were only 3 problem sets where we were able to practice STATA and Matlab. The problem sets had very good instructions; I have never seen such thoughtful problem sets! The course had no notable weakness.
love the prof and content. perhaps more class discussion rather than just the "leminar"
This course is structured very well, and the only comment I'd have is that it could benefit from slightly more evenly distributed work/projects.

Strength - The materials are extremely interesting and pertinent to current affairs. Professor Noguera breaks down complicated models in crystal clear terms and makes sure that students do not just mechanically reproduce numbers but can apply the languages and concepts appropriately in other contexts

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course was well structured to exist online

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, I highly recommend this course. International Trade is fundamental to the field of economics; it was humans' first economic activity millennia before we had the discipline of Economics! The course is very manageable, and you learn a lot about General Equilibrium trade models. The course helps you get comfortable with fixed-effects estimation which is one of the most important techniques in econometric panel data analysis. The exams are fair, and the three problem sets are very well planned-out by Prof. Noguera.
yes. a very chill econ elective. not that mathy nor do u need much coding/stats experience.
I would certainly recommend it! A great class.
